By His command, the girl’s spirit returns and she gets up. Jesus tenderly refers to her as “child” (or “little girl”), and this powerful miracle restores her to life.

scriptures.text: Do not stop him, for the one who is not against you is for you.
scriptures.context_description: When John reports that they stopped someone casting out demons in Jesus’ name (because he wasn’t part of their group), Jesus corrects the disciples. He tells them not to hinder such a person. It’s a positive, inclusive teaching that anyone acting in Jesus’ name and not opposing Him is effectively on their side.

scriptures.text: You have answered correctly; do this, and you will live.
scriptures.context_description: A lawyer tests Jesus about inheriting eternal life and correctly cites the greatest commandments (love God and love neighbor). Jesus positively acknowledges the correct answer and encourages him to practice that love, promising that living out those commandments leads to life.

scriptures.text: You go, and do likewise.
scriptures.context_description: After telling the Parable of the Good Samaritan, Jesus asks the lawyer which person was a true neighbor. When the lawyer identifies the merciful Samaritan, Jesus exhorts him to follow that example. It’s a call to compassionate action, indicating approval of mercy and urging the lawyer to implement it.

scriptures.text: My friends, do not fear those who kill the body, and after that have nothing more that they can do.
scriptures.context_description: Jesus addresses His disciples affectionately as “friends” and encourages them not to fear human opponents or persecutors. Though people can kill the body, they cannot harm the soul. This comfort strengthens them to face persecution with courage.

scriptures.text: Fear not, little flock, for it is your Father’s good pleasure to give you the kingdom.
scriptures.context_description: Jesus speaks tenderly to His disciples, calling them His “little flock.” He tells them not to be afraid because God the Father is delighted to give them the kingdom. It’s a profoundly reassuring statement about God’s gracious will and care for them, even as they are a small, vulnerable group.

scriptures.text: Zacchaeus, hurry and come down, for I must stay at your house today.
scriptures.context_description: Seeing Zacchaeus (a chief tax collector) perched in a sycamore tree to get a glimpse of Him, Jesus calls him by name. In a warm, public gesture, Jesus invites Himself over to Zacchaeus’s home. This positive interaction leads to Zacchaeus’s joyful hospitality and repentance.

scriptures.text: Today salvation has come to this house, since he also is a son of Abraham. For the Son of Man came to seek and to save the lost.
scriptures.context_description: After Zacchaeus repents and pledges to make restitution for wrongs, Jesus declares that salvation has come to Zacchaeus’s household. He affirms Zacchaeus as a true descendant of Abraham (a member of God’s people) and explains His own mission to seek out and save those who are lost, like Zacchaeus had been.

scriptures.text: I tell you, if these were silent, the very stones would cry out.
scriptures.context_description: When Pharisees urge Jesus to rebuke His disciples for praising Him as King during the triumphal entry, Jesus refuses. Instead, He asserts that if the crowd didn’t shout, the stones themselves would – implying that His messianic identity will be proclaimed no matter what. It’s a poetic way of approving the praise being offered to Him.

scriptures.text: I have earnestly desired to eat this Passover with you before I suffer.
scriptures.context_description: At the Last Supper, Jesus expresses to His apostles how deeply He longed to share that Passover meal with them prior to His upcoming suffering. It’s a heartfelt statement of love and desire for fellowship with them in these final hours.

scriptures.text: But not so with you. Rather, let the greatest among you become as the youngest, and the leader as one who serves.
scriptures.context_description: During the Last Supper, the disciples were arguing about who among them was the greatest. Jesus addresses them to redefine greatness in positive terms of humility and service. He gently corrects their mindset by teaching that true greatness in His kingdom is shown by serving others, as He Himself does.

scriptures.text: Simon, Simon, behold, Satan demanded to have you, that he might sift you like wheat, but I have prayed for you that your faith may not fail. And when you have turned again, strengthen your brothers.
scriptures.context_description: Jesus speaks directly to Peter (calling him by his old name, Simon) with a mix of warning and encouragement. He reveals that Satan wants to test all the disciples (“you” in verse 31 is plural), but Jesus has specifically prayed for Peter’s own faith not to fail completely. Jesus also looks beyond Peter’s impending denial, foreseeing his repentance (“turned again”) and instructing him to support the others afterward. This shows Jesus’ personal care for Peter and confidence in his restoration.

scriptures.text: Truly, I say to you, today you will be with me in Paradise.
scriptures.context_description: While Jesus was on the cross, one of the criminals crucified next to Him expressed faith, asking Jesus to remember him. Jesus responds with a profound promise: that very day the repentant thief would join Him in Paradise. It’s an assurance of salvation and a comforting word given in the midst of suffering.

scriptures.text: Peace to you!
scriptures.context_description: After His resurrection, Jesus suddenly appears among His disciples who were gathered in a locked room, and He greets them with a blessing of peace. This calms and reassures the frightened disciples, confirming that it is truly Jesus alive among them.

scriptures.text: Come and you will see.
scriptures.context_description: When two of John the Baptist’s disciples ask Jesus where He is staying, He extends an open invitation: “Come and see.” Jesus welcomes them to spend the day with Him. This positive response begins the relationship where these men (one of whom was Andrew) become His followers.

scriptures.text: You are Simon the son of John. You shall be called Cephas.
scriptures.context_description: Upon meeting Simon (brought by his brother Andrew), Jesus immediately gives him a new name, Cephas (or Peter, meaning Rock). This is a prophetic affirmation of the role Simon Peter will have. It’s a positive, identity-shaping moment where Jesus sees Peter’s future potential.

scriptures.text: Behold, an Israelite indeed, in whom there is no deceit!
scriptures.context_description: Jesus says this as He sees Nathanael approaching. He positively characterizes Nathanael as a true Israelite with a genuine heart (no deceit). This surprised Nathanael, as it showed Jesus knew his character even before meeting him, leading to Nathanael’s faith in Jesus.

scriptures.text: Before Philip called you, when you were under the fig tree, I saw you.
scriptures.context_description: Nathanael asks Jesus how He knows about him. Jesus reveals a supernatural knowledge: He saw Nathanael under a fig tree even before Philip brought him. This personal insight convinces Nathanael that Jesus is the Son of God. It’s a gentle unveiling of Jesus’ omniscience in a way that wins Nathanael’s trust.

scriptures.text: Because I said to you, ‘I saw you under the fig tree,’ do you believe? You will see greater things than these.
scriptures.context_description: After Nathanael responds in faith, Jesus kindly teases him for believing just from that one sign, and then promises that Nathanael (and the other disciples) will witness even greater revelations and miracles. It’s an encouraging hint at the amazing things to come.

scriptures.text: If you knew the gift of God, and who it is that is saying to you, ‘Give me a drink,’ you would have asked him, and he would have given you living water.
scriptures.context_description: At the well in Samaria, Jesus engages a Samaritan woman. He hints that if she truly understood who He is (the Messiah and God’s gift), she would ask Him for “living water” – meaning eternal life and the Holy Spirit. This statement piques her interest and begins a life-changing conversation, offering her a chance for spiritual satisfaction.

scriptures.text: I who speak to you am he.
scriptures.context_description: In the same conversation at the well, when the Samaritan woman mentions the coming Messiah, Jesus reveals Himself plainly as the Messiah (“he”). This is a remarkably direct and positive self-disclosure to someone marginalized. It leads the woman to faith and to share the news with her town.

scriptures.text: Go; your son will live.
scriptures.context_description: A royal official from Capernaum implores Jesus to heal his dying son. Jesus simply speaks these words, assuring the man that his son will recover. The man believes Jesus and departs; later he discovers his son was healed at that exact moment. Jesus’ words gave the man hope and indeed brought healing.

scriptures.text: Do you want to be healed?
scriptures.context_description: At the pool of Bethesda, Jesus asks a man who had been disabled for 38 years this question. It may seem obvious, but Jesus’ question invites the man to voice his desire and focus his hope. It’s a compassionate engagement with someone who had lost hope, right before Jesus heals him.

scriptures.text: Get up, take up your bed, and walk.
scriptures.context_description: Jesus commands the invalid at Bethesda with these words. The man immediately becomes well, picks up his mat, and walks. This direct address instantly heals a decades-long paralysis, demonstrating Jesus’ life-giving authority and mercy.

scriptures.text: It was not that this man sinned, or his parents, but that the works of God might be displayed in him.
scriptures.context_description: Jesus speaks to His disciples about a man born blind (within the blind man’s hearing). They assumed the blindness was punishment for sin. Jesus corrects this, saying the blindness wasn’t due to personal sin but allowed so that God’s power could be shown. This reframes the situation positively – the man’s healing will glorify God, which Jesus then accomplishes.

scriptures.text: You have seen him, and it is he who is speaking to you.
scriptures.context_description: After healing the man born blind (who was later cast out by the Pharisees), Jesus finds him and asks if he believes in the Son of Man (the Messiah). The man asks who that is, and Jesus reveals that it is Himself. This gentle revelation leads the healed man to worship Jesus, completing not just his physical sight but his spiritual insight.

scriptures.text: Your brother will rise again.
scriptures.context_description: Jesus comforts Martha after her brother Lazarus has died. She expresses sorrow that Jesus hadn’t arrived sooner. Jesus assures her that Lazarus will rise. Martha initially interprets this as a reference to the final resurrection, but Jesus is also hinting at the immediate miracle He is about to perform (raising Lazarus that very day).

scriptures.text: I am the resurrection and the life. Whoever believes in me, though he die, yet shall he live, and everyone who lives and believes in me shall never die. Do you believe this?
scriptures.context_description: Continuing His conversation with Martha, Jesus makes a profound declaration of His identity and power over death, promising eternal life to those who believe in Him. He then invites Martha to affirm her faith. This interaction both consoles her and challenges her to trust Him even in the face of her brother’s death.

scriptures.text: Lazarus, come out.
scriptures.context_description: Standing at Lazarus’s tomb, Jesus cries out this short command. Despite Lazarus having been dead for four days, Jesus’ word causes Lazarus to come back to life and exit the tomb, still wrapped in graveclothes. It’s a dramatic display of Jesus’ life-giving power spoken directly to a dead man, and Lazarus responds by rising.

scriptures.text: The light is among you for a little while longer. Walk while you have the light, lest darkness overtake you... While you have the light, believe in the light, that you may become sons of light.
scriptures.context_description: Addressing a crowd in Jerusalem just days before His crucifixion, Jesus refers to Himself as the light present with them. He urges the people to take advantage of this opportunity (“walk” and “believe” in the light) so that they can become children of light. It’s a plea for them to respond in faith to Him before it’s too late.

scriptures.text: What I am doing you do not understand now, but afterward you will understand.
scriptures.context_description: When Jesus began washing the disciples’ feet, Peter objected, not understanding why Jesus, their Master, would do a servant’s task. Jesus gently explains to Peter that though he doesn’t grasp it at the moment, he will later. This is a patient reassurance that there is a purpose to Jesus’ humble act (teaching them about servanthood) that will become clear.

scriptures.text: A new commandment I give to you, that you love one another: just as I have loved you, you also are to love one another.
scriptures.context_description: During the Last Supper, Jesus addresses His disciples and gives them a “new” commandment. It’s an exhortation to show selfless, Christ-like love to each other. By calling it new and referencing His own love as the standard, Jesus highlights the importance of mutual love as the defining mark of His followers.

scriptures.text: Let not your hearts be troubled. Believe in God; believe also in me.
scriptures.context_description: Knowing His disciples are anxious about His talk of leaving and the trials ahead, Jesus comforts them. He tells them to calm their troubled hearts by trusting in God and in Himself. This is the opening of a deeply reassuring discourse where He promises them a place in the Father’s house and the coming of the Holy Spirit.

scriptures.text: Peace I leave with you; my peace I give to you... Let not your hearts be troubled, neither let them be afraid.
scriptures.context_description: Still in the upper room, Jesus bestows His peace upon the disciples. He differentiates His peace from what the world gives and urges them again not to be troubled or fearful. It’s a tender benediction of inner peace, meant to sustain them after He departs.

scriptures.text: No longer do I call you servants... but I have called you friends, for all that I have heard from my Father I have made known to you.
scriptures.context_description: In His farewell discourse, Jesus elevates the relationship with His disciples from master-servant to friendship. He explains that He has shared with them everything He learned from the Father, treating them as close friends who know His heart and plans. This is a gracious, affirming statement that shows the intimacy and love He has for them.

scriptures.text: You did not choose me, but I chose you and appointed you that you should go and bear fruit and that your fruit should abide...
scriptures.context_description: Jesus reminds the disciples that it was His initiative to choose them. He encourages them by stating He has a purpose for them: to produce lasting spiritual fruit in the world (such as new disciples or righteous deeds). This gives them confidence and identity, knowing Jesus personally selected and commissioned them for a fruitful mission.

scriptures.text: In the world you will have tribulation. But take heart; I have overcome the world.
scriptures.context_description: Jesus concludes His farewell talk with the disciples by acknowledging they will face troubles in this world. Yet He tells them to have courage because He has conquered the world (through His victory over sin, death, and Satan). This triumphant assurance is meant to give them peace and confidence as they face hardship.

scriptures.text: Woman, behold, your son!... Behold, your mother!
scriptures.context_description: Even while suffering on the cross, Jesus addresses His mother Mary and the Apostle John with great care. He calls Mary “Woman” respectfully and entrusts her to John’s care (“behold, your son”), and likewise tells John to treat Mary as his own mother. This ensures Mary will be looked after. It’s a loving provision for His mother, showing Jesus’ concern for others even in His agony.

scriptures.text: Mary.
scriptures.context_description: Outside the empty tomb on resurrection morning, Mary Magdalene did not recognize the risen Jesus at first. Jesus simply speaks her name, “Mary.” That one word, said in the familiar way Jesus spoke it, immediately opens her eyes to His identity. It’s an intensely personal and joyful moment as Mary turns and recognizes her “Rabboni” (Teacher).

scriptures.text: Do not cling to me, for I have not yet ascended to the Father; but go to my brothers and say to them...
scriptures.context_description: After Mary Magdalene recognizes Jesus, she apparently grabs hold of Him. Jesus gently tells her not to hold on to Him, since He has not yet ascended to the Father (implying she doesn’t have to fear losing Him immediately). He then commissions Mary to go announce to His “brothers” (the disciples) the news of His upcoming ascension to God the Father. This not only gives Mary a mission as the first witness of the resurrection, but also conveys Jesus’ continued relationship with the disciples.

scriptures.text: Peace be with you. As the Father has sent me, even so I am sending you.
scriptures.context_description: On the evening of His resurrection, Jesus greets the gathered disciples (minus Thomas) with a blessing of peace, calming their fears. He then commissions them for their apostolic mission: just as God the Father sent Jesus into the world, now Jesus sends His followers to continue His work. This is both a comforting and empowering address, establishing them as His emissaries.

scriptures.text: Put your finger here, and see my hands; and put out your hand, and place it in my side. Do not disbelieve, but believe.
scriptures.context_description: A week after the resurrection, Jesus appears again, this time when Thomas (who had doubted) is present. Jesus directly addresses Thomas’s expressed skepticism. He invites Thomas to touch His crucifixion wounds as proof and urges him to stop doubting and believe. Jesus’ approach is gentle but direct, providing Thomas the evidence he asked for and calling him to faith.

scriptures.text: Have you believed because you have seen me? Blessed are those who have not seen and yet have believed.
scriptures.context_description: After Thomas responds in faith (“My Lord and my God!”), Jesus addresses him again. He asks rhetorically if Thomas only believed because he saw physical proof. Jesus then pronounces a blessing on future believers who will believe in Him without seeing Him in person. This both acknowledges Thomas’s new faith and highlights the even greater blessedness of faith that doesn’t require sight.

scriptures.text: Children, do you have any fish?
scriptures.context_description: The resurrected Jesus stands on the shore at dawn while some disciples are out fishing (unaware it’s Jesus). He affectionately calls out to them as “children” and asks if they’ve caught anything. This friendly address preludes the miracle where He directs them to a massive catch of fish and is part of Jesus’ gentle approach before revealing Himself to them.

scriptures.text: Come and have breakfast.
scriptures.context_description: After the disciples come ashore with the miraculous catch, they find Jesus has prepared a charcoal fire with fish and bread. Jesus invites them to eat breakfast with Him. This is a warm, hospitable gesture, showing Jesus’ care for their physical hunger and His desire for fellowship. It likely reminded them of earlier feedings and further confirmed His identity.

scriptures.text: Simon, son of John, do you love me?... Feed my sheep.
scriptures.context_description: The third time Jesus asks Peter if Peter loves Him (mirroring Peter’s three earlier denials), Peter is hurt but affirms his love. Jesus then gives the command “Feed my sheep,” entrusting Peter with the care of His followers. In this interaction, Jesus restores Peter to ministry. Though it’s a challenging moment for Peter, it is fundamentally a positive reinstatement and a charge that shows Jesus still trusts and commissions him.

categories.category_description: Instances where Jesus speaks in a corrective, stern, or confrontational manner. These include rebukes of sin or lack of faith, warnings of judgment, and forceful challenges toward individuals or groups whose actions or attitudes are wrong. Such interactions show Jesus’ holiness and His willingness to directly address error or hypocrisy.

scriptures.text: Be gone, Satan! For it is written, "You shall worship the Lord your God and him only shall you serve."
scriptures.context_description: During His temptation in the wilderness, Jesus rebukes the devil who was enticing Him with power and glory in exchange for worship. Jesus commands Satan to leave and quotes Scripture that only God is to be worshiped. It’s a strong dismissal of Satan’s influence.

scriptures.text: Foxes have holes, and birds of the air have nests, but the Son of Man has nowhere to lay his head.
scriptures.context_description: A scribe enthusiastically offered to follow Jesus wherever He went. Jesus responds with this sobering statement, implying that following Him means a life of hardship and homelessness. He is cautioning the would-be disciple about the cost of discipleship.

scriptures.text: Follow me, and leave the dead to bury their own dead.
scriptures.context_description: Another disciple asked for delay in following Jesus until he could bury his father. Jesus’ reply is a sharp challenge that allegiance to Him must come first. “Leave the dead to bury their own dead” suggests that the spiritually dead can take care of routine obligations – the man should immediately follow Jesus. It’s a stern test of priorities.

scriptures.text: Why are you afraid, O you of little faith?
scriptures.context_description: Jesus says this to His disciples during the storm on the Sea of Galilee. As their boat was being swamped, they panicked and woke Him. Before calming the storm, Jesus rebukes their fear and small faith. His tone implies that by now they should trust Him more, even in dangerous circumstances.

scriptures.text: Why do you think evil in your hearts?
scriptures.context_description: When Jesus told the paralyzed man his sins were forgiven (Matt 9:2), some scribes silently accused Jesus of blasphemy in their minds. Jesus, knowing their thoughts, confronts them with this question. He calls their skeptical, accusatory thoughts “evil,” thereby exposing their unbelief and malice.

scriptures.text: Go away, for the girl is not dead but sleeping.
scriptures.context_description: Arriving at Jairus’s house where mourners were wailing over the dead girl, Jesus tells the crowd to leave because the girl is only sleeping (meaning her death will be temporary). They laughed at Him, but He put them out. His command “Go away” is a dismissive, authoritative order clearing out the scornful unbelief before He raises the girl. It’s stern in that context.

scriptures.text: And if you had known what this means, 'I desire mercy, and not sacrifice,' you would not have condemned the guiltless.
scriptures.context_description: Jesus addresses the Pharisees who criticized His disciples for plucking grain on the Sabbath. He quotes Hosea 6:6 and rebukes them for their lack of understanding. By saying “if you had known,” He implies they are ignorant of God’s heart for mercy. He scolds them for condemning His innocent disciples over ritual matters, exposing their legalistic attitude.

scriptures.text: You brood of vipers! How can you speak good, when you are evil?
scriptures.context_description: Confronting the Pharisees who had just attributed His miracles to Satan (Matthew 12:24), Jesus delivers a harsh rebuke. He calls them a “brood of vipers” (offspring of snakes), indicating their poisonous, deceitful nature. He questions how they could say anything good since their hearts are evil. This interaction shows Jesus’ righteous anger at their blasphemous and hypocritical words.

scriptures.text: An evil and adulterous generation seeks for a sign, but no sign will be given to it except the sign of the prophet Jonah.
scriptures.context_description: Some scribes and Pharisees demanded a miraculous sign from Jesus to prove Himself. Jesus responds by condemning their attitude: He labels that generation as wicked and unfaithful (spiritually “adulterous”) for demanding signs when plenty of evidence has been given. He promises them only the sign of Jonah (His resurrection after three days). It’s a stern refusal that exposes their hard-hearted unbelief.

scriptures.text: You hypocrites! Well did Isaiah prophesy of you...
scriptures.context_description: When Pharisees and scribes criticized Jesus’ disciples for not following ritual handwashing traditions, Jesus first accuses them of voiding God’s commands for the sake of their traditions (Matt 15:3-6), then calls them “hypocrites.” He quotes Isaiah’s prophecy about people honoring God with lips while their hearts are far away (Matt 15:8-9). This direct name-calling and Scripture application is a blunt exposure of their two-faced religiosity.

scriptures.text: It is not right to take the children’s bread and throw it to the dogs.
scriptures.context_description: Initially, Jesus gives this stark reply to the Canaanite woman begging Him to heal her demon-possessed daughter. By “children,” He means the Israelites, and by “dogs,” a common term Jews used for Gentiles. This sounds very harsh, implying that His ministry (the children’s bread) isn’t meant for Gentiles at that moment. Jesus’ words test the woman’s humility and faith; she accepts the challenge and replies cleverly, and Jesus ultimately praises her faith and heals her daughter. But this statement itself is deliberately offensive, making it a negative interaction in tone.

scriptures.text: O you of little faith, why are you discussing among yourselves the fact that you have no bread?
scriptures.context_description: After Jesus warned the disciples about the “leaven of the Pharisees and Sadducees,” they misunderstood and thought He was scolding them for forgetting bread. Aware of their confusion, Jesus rebukes them for their small faith. Having just recently fed multitudes miraculously, they shouldn’t worry about bread or miss His metaphor. His question chides them for still focusing on physical bread and not trusting His provision.

scriptures.text: Get behind me, Satan! You are a hindrance to me. For you are not setting your mind on the things of God, but on the things of man.
scriptures.context_description: When Peter tried to dissuade Jesus from going to the cross (after Jesus predicted His death), Jesus turned and delivered this fierce rebuke to Peter. He even addresses Peter as “Satan,” meaning Peter was speaking under Satan’s influence by tempting Jesus to avoid suffering. Jesus calls Peter a stumbling block and explains that Peter’s thinking is human-centered, not aligned with God’s plan. It’s one of Jesus’ most severe corrections, aimed at a disciple He loved, because of the gravity of the issue.

scriptures.text: O faithless and twisted generation, how long am I to be with you? How long am I to bear with you? Bring him here to me.
scriptures.context_description: Jesus says this in frustration when He comes down from the Transfiguration and finds the disciples unable to cast a demon out of a boy. He addresses the crowd (and possibly the disciples) as a “faithless and perverse generation.” His rhetorical questions (“How long...?”) express disappointment at their persistent lack of faith. He then tells them to bring the boy to Him, after which He casts out the demon. The rebuke highlights Jesus’ expectation for greater faith and His weariness of unbelief.

scriptures.text: Because of your little faith. For truly, I say to you, if you have faith like a grain of mustard seed... nothing will be impossible for you.
scriptures.context_description: Later, when the disciples privately ask why they could not cast out the demon, Jesus tells them it was due to their small faith. He rebukes their unbelief but also teaches that even a tiny amount of genuine faith (as small as a mustard seed) can accomplish great things. While part of this is an encouragement, the initial answer clearly points out their failure as stemming from deficiency in faith.

scriptures.text: Truly, I say to you, unless you turn and become like children, you will never enter the kingdom of heaven.
scriptures.context_description: When the disciples asked Jesus who is greatest in the kingdom, Jesus set a child before them and delivered this strong statement. By saying they won’t even enter the kingdom unless they change and humble themselves like children, He implicitly rebukes their pride and argument over status. It’s a corrective warning that their attitude must drastically change.

scriptures.text: If you would be perfect, go, sell what you possess and give to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven; and come, follow me.
scriptures.context_description: Jesus says this to the rich young ruler who claimed to have kept all the commandments and asked what he still lacked. Jesus, knowing the man’s attachment to wealth, issues a challenging directive: to sell all he has, give to the poor, and then follow Jesus. This exposes the man’s true heart—sadly, the man leaves sorrowful because he can’t part with his riches. Jesus’ words, while essentially an invitation, function as a pointed confrontation of the idol in the man’s life (his wealth).

scriptures.text: You do not know what you are asking. Are you able to drink the cup that I am to drink?
scriptures.context_description: When James and John (via their mother) request the top positions in Jesus’ kingdom, Jesus first responds with “You don’t realize what you’re asking.” He then asks if they can endure the suffering (“the cup”) He must face. This interaction is a mild reproof of their ambition and misunderstanding of greatness. Jesus implies they are seeking honor without comprehending the cost (His upcoming suffering).

scriptures.text: It is written, 'My house shall be called a house of prayer,' but you make it a den of robbers.
scriptures.context_description: Jesus speaks this while cleansing the temple in Jerusalem. He overturns the tables of the money-changers and drives out those selling animals, quoting Scripture (Isaiah 56:7 and Jeremiah 7:11). He condemns how they turned God’s house into a thieves’ hideout. This is a public and forceful rebuke of the merchants and religious authorities for corrupting the worship space with greed.

scriptures.text: Yes; have you never read, 'Out of the mouth of infants and nursing babies you have prepared praise'?
scriptures.context_description: After the temple cleansing, children in the temple courts were shouting praises to Jesus as the Son of David, and the chief priests became indignant. In reply, Jesus quotes Psalm 8:2 to justify the children’s praises. The rhetorical “have you never read?” is a jab at these learned leaders’ failure to recognize Scripture being fulfilled. It’s a subtle but pointed way of saying that even children recognize His messianic identity, whereas the religious leaders, who should know better, do not.

scriptures.text: Have you never read in the Scriptures: 'The stone that the builders rejected has become the cornerstone'?... Therefore I tell you, the kingdom of God will be taken away from you and given to a people producing its fruits.
scriptures.context_description: Speaking to the chief priests and Pharisees after the Parable of the Wicked Tenants, Jesus first cites Psalm 118:22 about the rejected stone becoming the cornerstone—implying that they (the builders) are rejecting Him (the cornerstone). He then delivers a severe warning: because of their rejection, God’s kingdom will be taken from them and given to others who will bear fruit. This is a pronouncement of judgment, essentially telling Israel’s religious leaders that their privileged position will be lost due to their unfaithfulness.

scriptures.text: Why put me to the test, you hypocrites?
scriptures.context_description: The Pharisees and Herodians tried to trap Jesus with a question about paying taxes to Caesar. Before answering, Jesus recognizes their malicious intent. He openly calls them out as hypocrites for testing Him. By labeling them this way, He exposes their insincerity—they weren’t seeking truth but trying to ensnare Him. It’s a sharp reproach that precedes His clever answer about rendering to Caesar and God.

scriptures.text: You are wrong, because you know neither the Scriptures nor the power of God.
scriptures.context_description: Jesus says this to the Sadducees who posed a trick question about marriage at the resurrection (a doctrine they denied). He bluntly tells them they’re mistaken in their premise. He attributes their error to ignorance of both Scripture and God’s power. This is a direct correction of their theological error and a critique of their spiritual blindness, delivered without any sugar-coating.

scriptures.text: But woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you shut the kingdom of heaven in people’s faces...
scriptures.context_description: This is the first of a series of seven woes Jesus pronounces on the religious leaders in Matthew 23. He denounces the scribes and Pharisees as hypocrites, and specifically here, accuses them of preventing others from entering God’s kingdom (through their legalism and opposition to Jesus), while they themselves aren’t entering either. The “woe” is a declaration of judgment and sorrow for their spiritually deadly behavior.

scriptures.text: Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you travel across sea and land to make a single proselyte, and when he becomes one, you make him twice as much a child of hell as yourselves.
scriptures.context_description: Another woe against the religious leaders. Jesus condemns their zeal in making converts to their brand of Judaism, noting the tragic result: the convert becomes even more hell-bound than the Pharisees themselves. This indicates the Pharisees’ influence is spiritually ruinous. Calling them “children of hell” and saying they produce the same is extremely strong language, emphasizing how severely off-track their religion is.

scriptures.text: Woe to you, blind guides, who say, 'If anyone swears by the temple, it is nothing; but if anyone swears by the gold of the temple, he is bound by his oath.'
scriptures.context_description: Here Jesus calls the Pharisees “blind guides,” mocking the fact that they are supposed to be spiritual leaders but are utterly blind to truth. He references one of their legalistic teachings about oaths—showing how they created loopholes (distinguishing between swearing by the temple vs. its gold) to evade honesty. This woe denounces their foolish and deceptive casuistry and highlights their spiritual blindness.

scriptures.text: Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you tithe mint and dill and cumin, and have neglected the weightier matters of the law... You blind guides, straining out a gnat and swallowing a camel!
scriptures.context_description: Jesus rebukes the Pharisees for their warped priorities. They meticulously tithe even the smallest garden herbs, yet they ignore the more important moral commands like justice, mercy, and faithfulness. He calls them blind guides again, using a vivid image: they filter out a tiny unclean insect (gnat) from their drink but gulp down a huge unclean animal (camel). This exaggeration underscores how they fuss over minutiae but commit great injustices. It’s a scathing indictment of their hypocrisy and misplaced focus.

scriptures.text: Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you clean the outside of the cup and the plate, but inside they are full of greed and self-indulgence.
scriptures.context_description: In this woe, Jesus compares the Pharisees to a dish that’s washed on the outside but filthy inside. It symbolizes their lives: they maintain an appearance of religious purity outwardly, but internally they are corrupt—filled with greed and indulgence. Jesus is condemning their focus on external rituals and reputation while harboring sinful motives and desires. It’s a clear call-out of their inner moral decay.

scriptures.text: Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you are like whitewashed tombs, which outwardly appear beautiful, but within are full of dead people’s bones and all uncleanness.
scriptures.context_description: Jesus uses another striking image to expose the Pharisees’ hypocrisy. He likens them to tombs that have been painted white on the outside (which was done to make them look nice and to warn people to avoid ritual impurity) but inside are full of death and decay. The Pharisees similarly look pious externally, but their hearts are full of corruption and death. This simile bluntly highlights the contrast between their public image and their true spiritual state.

scriptures.text: Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you build the tombs of the prophets and decorate the monuments of the righteous...
scriptures.context_description: Jesus condemns the Pharisees for honoring the Old Testament prophets with tombs and memorials while failing to heed their message. He implies that despite outwardly venerating slain prophets, they are the same as those who killed the prophets (in fact, they are plotting to kill Jesus, the greatest prophet). Following verses (23:30-32) make clear that they bear the same murderous mindset. Thus, this woe accuses them of hypocrisy in claiming they wouldn’t have killed prophets, while they carry the same guilt in their hearts.

scriptures.text: You serpents, you brood of vipers, how are you to escape being sentenced to hell?
scriptures.context_description: Toward the end of the woes, Jesus intensifies the condemnation. He directly calls the religious leaders “snakes” and a family of vipers, echoing John the Baptist’s earlier rebuke (Matthew 3:7). He then pointedly asks how they could possibly escape hell’s judgment. This rhetorical question implies that their behavior is so evil that damnation is certain without drastic repentance. It is an extremely severe and final warning about the peril of their souls.

scriptures.text: O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, the city that kills the prophets and stones those who are sent to it! How often would I have gathered your children together... and you were not willing!
scriptures.context_description: Here Jesus laments over Jerusalem with sorrow and frustration. Addressing the city (personifying its people and leaders), He acknowledges its history of murdering prophets and messengers from God. He then mournfully notes that He frequently longed to gather and protect her children as a hen does with chicks, but the city was unwilling. This is a negative interaction in the sense of a rebuke combined with grief – Jesus is both condemning the city’s hard-heartedness and expressing His heartbreak at their rejection of Him.

scriptures.text: Why do you trouble the woman? For she has done a beautiful thing to me.
scriptures.context_description: When Mary of Bethany anointed Jesus with expensive perfume, some disciples (led by Judas) criticized it as wasteful. Jesus comes to her defense with a sharp question to the critics. By asking why they are bothering her, He rebukes them for their harsh attitude. He then affirms the value of her act of devotion. While this statement defends Mary, it’s negative toward the disciples’ perspective, correcting their misguided indignation.

scriptures.text: Truly, I say to you, one of you will betray me.
scriptures.context_description: At the Last Supper, Jesus drops this solemn truth in front of all the Twelve. This assertion that one of His own disciples will hand Him over is not aimed at a specific individual by name here, but it’s a heavy indictment in the group setting. It causes each to question himself sorrowfully. It’s negative in that it exposes upcoming treachery among them, creating an atmosphere of dread and self-examination.

scriptures.text: You have said so.
scriptures.context_description: Judas, who intends to betray Jesus, asks, “Is it I, Rabbi?” Jesus answers with this phrase, essentially affirming Judas’s words. “You have said so” is a way of saying, “Yes, it is as you say.” This indirect confirmation serves as a personal confrontation to Judas without alerting the others explicitly. It’s a tense interaction, effectively unmasking Judas’s guilt to him. Jesus’ response is curt and laden with the weight of Judas’s impending betrayal.

scriptures.text: You will all fall away because of me this night, for it is written, 'I will strike the shepherd, and the sheep of the flock will be scattered.'
scriptures.context_description: On the Mount of Olives, just before His arrest, Jesus tells the disciples a hard truth: every one of them will abandon Him that very night. He supports this with a prophecy from Zechariah. This is a stern prediction that implies their coming failure of loyalty. It’s not a scolding in the moment, but it is a negative prophecy about their actions, likely delivered with a tone of sad certainty.

scriptures.text: Truly, I tell you, this very night, before the rooster crows, you will deny me three times.
scriptures.context_description: Jesus directs this prophecy to Peter specifically, after Peter insists he will never fall away. Jesus, with solemn certainty (“Truly, I tell you”), tells Peter that contrary to his claims, he will deny knowing Jesus three times before the rooster crows at dawn. This is a personal rebuke/warning to Peter’s overconfidence and a prediction of his imminent failure. It is clearly a painful and negative revelation for Peter to hear.

scriptures.text: So, could you not watch with me one hour?
scriptures.context_description: In Gethsemane, Jesus finds Peter, James, and John sleeping instead of keeping watch as He had asked. He addresses this question to Peter (whom He singles out by name in Mark’s account). The question is a mild rebuke expressing disappointment that they couldn’t stay awake and pray even for a short time while He agonized. It highlights their weakness during His hour of need.

scriptures.text: Watch and pray that you may not enter into temptation. The spirit indeed is willing, but the flesh is weak.
scriptures.context_description: Continuing in Gethsemane, Jesus admonishes the sleepy disciples. He commands them to stay alert and pray to avoid falling into temptation (knowing the trial that is coming with His arrest). He comments that though they may have good intentions (“willing spirit”), their human weakness is overpowering. This statement both warns and explains their failure. It’s corrective, urging them to overcome physical weakness through vigilance and prayer.

scriptures.text: Friend, do what you came to do.
scriptures.context_description: When Judas arrives in Gethsemane leading armed men and betrays Jesus with a kiss, Jesus responds with this statement. Calling Judas “Friend” in this context is poignant and possibly ironic, as Judas is acting as an enemy. “Do what you came to do” is essentially Jesus permitting the betrayal to proceed. While not a harsh insult, it’s a firm and resigned acknowledgment of Judas’s treachery. It carries a tone of sad resolve and dismisses Judas to carry out his deed.

scriptures.text: Put your sword back into its place. For all who take the sword will perish by the sword.
scriptures.context_description: When Peter (identified in John’s Gospel) struck the high priest’s servant with a sword during Jesus’ arrest, Jesus rebukes him. He commands Peter to sheath his weapon and then issues a proverb/warning that violence breeds violence (“those who live by the sword die by the sword”). This is a stern correction of Peter’s attempt to fight, indicating that Jesus will not resist arrest with force and that His followers should not resort to violence.

scriptures.text: Have you come out as against a robber, with swords and clubs to capture me? Day after day I sat in the temple teaching, and you did not seize me.
scriptures.context_description: As He’s being arrested, Jesus addresses the crowd of soldiers, temple guards, and leaders. He calls out the absurdity and cowardice of their approach — they’ve come armed as if He were a dangerous criminal, yet He was peacefully teaching in public every day and they never laid hands on Him then. This critique shames the authorities for their clandestine, forceful tactics. It’s spoken as an indictment of their intimidation and duplicity.

scriptures.text: You have said so. But I tell you, from now on you will see the Son of Man seated at the right hand of Power and coming on the clouds of heaven.
scriptures.context_description: During His trial before the Jewish Sanhedrin, the high priest demands Jesus to declare if He is the Messiah, the Son of God. Jesus first responds “You have said so,” essentially affirming the charge in their words. Then He delivers a powerful declaration: citing Daniel 7:13 and Psalm 110:1, He predicts that they will see Him, the Son of Man, exalted at God’s right hand and returning in glory. This is a bold pronouncement of His divine authority to those who are condemning Him. It’s perceived as blasphemy by the council and leads to their violent reaction. Jesus’ words are not a rebuke in the conventional sense, but they are a confrontational truth claim in the face of His accusers, effectively warning them of His future vindication and their judgment.

scriptures.text: Why were you looking for me? Did you not know that I must be in my Father’s house?
scriptures.context_description: At age 12, after Mary and Joseph found Him in the Temple following a frantic three-day search, young Jesus responds with these questions. He mildly chides His parents for not knowing where He’d be. The correction lies in reminding them of His unique identity and mission (“my Father’s house” meaning God’s Temple). It’s a perplexing but firm reply that shows Jesus expected them to understand His priorities, even at that age.

scriptures.text: Truly, I say to you, no prophet is acceptable in his hometown.
scriptures.context_description: While speaking in the synagogue of Nazareth (His hometown), Jesus anticipates the crowd’s skepticism toward Him. He makes this proverbial statement comparing Himself to prophets rejected by their own people. This is a rebuke of their underlying unbelief. He then recalls how Elijah and Elisha blessed Gentiles instead of Israelites, implying that Nazareth’s rejection of Him will cost them. The crowd takes great offense and attempts to kill Him, confirming the truth of His saying.

scriptures.text: Why do you call me 'Lord, Lord,' and not do what I tell you?
scriptures.context_description: In the conclusion of the Sermon on the Plain, Jesus directly challenges those listening. Many might profess Jesus as “Lord” verbally, but fail to obey His teachings. This pointed question exposes the inconsistency between their words and actions. It’s a general rebuke against empty lip-service devoid of obedience, urging true discipleship evidenced by doing what He says.

scriptures.text: O faithless and twisted generation, how long am I to be with you and bear with you?
scriptures.context_description: This mirrors Matthew 17:17 — after the disciples could not cast out a demon from a boy, Jesus expresses exasperation. Luke’s account (as part of 9:41) similarly shows Jesus lamenting the unbelief and perversity of the people (including perhaps His disciples). It underscores His frustration at their persistent lack of faith and spiritual insight. It’s both a rebuke and an expression of weariness at dealing with such persistent failure.

scriptures.text: No one who puts his hand to the plow and looks back is fit for the kingdom of God.
scriptures.context_description: To a man who said he wanted to follow Jesus but first wanted to say goodbye to his family, Jesus gives this stern proverb. It implies that discipleship requires single-minded commitment. Anyone who begins the journey with Jesus and keeps looking back longingly or is distracted by past ties is not suitable for God’s kingdom work. It’s a challenging correction against half-hearted or delayed commitment.

scriptures.text: Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida! For if the mighty works done in you had been done in Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago...
scriptures.context_description: Jesus pronounces woes on the Galilean towns of Chorazin and Bethsaida where He performed many miracles, yet they did not repent. He compares them unfavorably to the pagan cities of Tyre and Sidon, suggesting those cities would have repented if they saw such works. This is a strong indictment of Chorazin and Bethsaida’s hard-heartedness and a warning of coming judgment due to their unbelief.

scriptures.text: And you, Capernaum... you shall be brought down to Hades.
scriptures.context_description: Similarly, Jesus addresses Capernaum (the town that had been His base of operations and also witnessed many miracles). He asks rhetorically if Capernaum will be exalted to heaven and immediately answers that it will be brought down to Hades (the realm of the dead). This means that despite its privilege of Jesus’ presence and teaching, Capernaum faces severe judgment for not responding. It’s a grave warning and rebuke to that city’s inhabitants.

scriptures.text: But woe to you Pharisees! For you tithe mint and rue and every herb, and neglect justice and the love of God...
scriptures.context_description: During a dinner at a Pharisee’s house (Luke 11:37-52), Jesus pronounces a series of woes against the Pharisees and experts in the law, similar to Matthew 23. In this woe, He rebukes the Pharisees for their meticulous tithing of small garden herbs while neglecting the fundamental virtues of justice and love for God. It’s highlighting their inverted priorities and is a direct condemnation of their hypocrisy and majoring in minors. Jesus affirms they should do the small duties without leaving the big duties undone.

scriptures.text: Woe to you lawyers also! For you load people with burdens hard to bear, and you yourselves do not touch the burdens with one of your fingers.
scriptures.context_description: Here Jesus turns to the experts in the Law (scribes or 'lawyers'). He rebukes them for creating or promoting many legalistic rules that become heavy burdens on people’s shoulders, yet they themselves don’t help carry those burdens nor live by the spirit of them. Essentially, they make religion onerous for others while avoiding true responsibility themselves. Jesus calls this out as worthy of woe (judgment).

scriptures.text: Woe to you lawyers! For you have taken away the key of knowledge. You did not enter yourselves, and you hindered those who were entering.
scriptures.context_description: In this final woe at that dinner, Jesus accuses the scholars of the Law of actually obscuring God’s truth (“the key of knowledge”) from the people. Their interpretations and traditions have not led them into true understanding or salvation, and worse, they block others from finding the truth. It’s a devastating critique: they, the supposed guides to scripture, have become obstacles to knowing God. Jesus condemns them for preventing people from entering the kingdom by their false teaching.

scriptures.text: But I will warn you whom to fear: fear him who, after he has killed, has authority to cast into hell. Yes, I tell you, fear him!
scriptures.context_description: Teaching His disciples, Jesus issues this strong warning about proper fear. Instead of fearing human beings who can only kill the body, Jesus says the one to fear is God, who has the authority over eternal judgment (to cast into hell after death). His repeated “fear him!” emphatically corrects any misplaced fear. While not directed at a single person as a rebuke, it’s a forceful admonition about taking God’s judgment seriously, countering the disciples’ tendency to fear man more than God.

scriptures.text: Man, who made me a judge or arbitrator over you?
scriptures.context_description: A man from a crowd asked Jesus to intervene in a family inheritance dispute. Jesus addresses him abruptly as “Man” (a form of address showing some distance) and declines the request, essentially saying it’s not His role to settle such civil disputes. The question implies a rebuke: Jesus didn’t come as a financial arbitrator, and the man’s request was out of place. Immediately after, Jesus warns the crowd about greed (Luke 12:15). So this statement dismisses the man’s demand and indirectly corrects his priorities.

scriptures.text: No, I tell you; but unless you repent, you will all likewise perish.
scriptures.context_description: Discussing recent tragedies (some Galileans killed by Pilate, and others killed by a tower collapse), Jesus twice emphasizes this point (in verses 3 and 5). The people thought victims might have been worse sinners. Jesus refutes that and instead warns that they all must repent or they too will face destruction. This statement is a general call to repentance delivered as a stern warning: it shifts the focus from others’ sins to the listeners’ own need to repent, under threat of perishing.

scriptures.text: You hypocrites! Does not each of you on the Sabbath untie his ox or his donkey from the manger and lead it away to water?
scriptures.context_description: After Jesus heals a disabled woman on the Sabbath in a synagogue, the synagogue ruler indignantly says healing should be done on other days. Jesus responds by angrily calling out the hypocrisy. He points out that every one of them would do the work of untying and watering their livestock on the Sabbath (an accepted necessity), yet they objected to a woman being freed from a crippling condition on the Sabbath. By highlighting this inconsistency, Jesus shames the religious leaders for caring more about animals than a person and for their hypocritical application of Sabbath rules.

scriptures.text: Is it lawful to heal on the Sabbath, or not?
scriptures.context_description: At a Pharisee’s house on the Sabbath, a man with dropsy (swelling) stood before Jesus. Knowing the Pharisees were watching to accuse Him, Jesus asks them this pointed question before healing the man. The Pharisees remain silent. Jesus’ question is a challenge to their strict Sabbath interpretations. It functions as a rebuke by forcing them to consider the righteousness of doing good (healing) on the Sabbath. Their silence indicates either their stubborn refusal to engage or that they have no reasonable answer without condemning themselves.

scriptures.text: You are those who justify yourselves before men, but God knows your hearts. For what is exalted among men is an abomination in the sight of God.
scriptures.context_description: When the Pharisees sneered at Jesus’ teaching about money (Luke 16:14), Jesus addressed them with this indictment. He accuses them of being concerned with outward appearance and human approval (“justify yourselves before men”) while God sees their true inner motives. He then delivers a general maxim that what people highly value (implying wealth or status, which the Pharisees loved) can be detestable to God. This is a strong rebuke uncovering their love of money and false piety, reminding them that God judges the heart.

scriptures.text: Were not ten cleansed? Where are the nine?
scriptures.context_description: After Jesus healed ten lepers and only one (a Samaritan) returned to thank Him, Jesus asks these questions. His tone clearly expresses disappointment that the other nine (who were Israelites) did not return to give thanks to God. By publicly asking “Where are the nine?”, Jesus is implicitly rebuking their lack of gratitude. He commends the foreigner’s faith but highlights the ingratitude of the rest. It’s a mild yet pointed chastisement of those who took their healing and failed to honor God.

scriptures.text: Judas, would you betray the Son of Man with a kiss?
scriptures.context_description: When Judas approaches to identify Jesus to the arresting party by kissing Him, Jesus speaks this heartbreaking question. By calling him by name and pointing out the bitter irony of betraying with a sign of affection, Jesus confronts Judas in the very act of betrayal. The question emphasizes the treachery and unnaturalness of what Judas is doing. It’s a personal rebuke that also highlights Judas’s ultimate act of falsehood.

scriptures.text: No more of this!
scriptures.context_description: After one of the disciples (Peter) struck the high priest’s servant and cut off his ear during the arrest attempt, Jesus emphatically stops the violence with “No more of this!” (or “Enough!”). He then heals the servant’s ear. This is a sharp command aimed at His followers to cease fighting. It rebukes the use of force in this situation and asserts Jesus’ willingness to be arrested according to God’s plan.

scriptures.text: Daughters of Jerusalem, do not weep for me, but weep for yourselves and for your children.
scriptures.context_description: As Jesus carries His cross to Golgotha, a group of women from Jerusalem wail in sympathy. Jesus turns to them with a prophetic warning: they should not cry for Him (for His suffering, which is temporary), but rather for themselves and their children. He’s indicating that terrible days are coming (referring to the siege and destruction of Jerusalem in 70 AD). This shifts the lament from His fate to the judgment looming over Jerusalem. While spoken with compassion, it is a negative prophecy that rebukes misplaced sorrow and urges them to recognize the real tragedy—their unrepentant city’s future.

scriptures.text: O foolish ones, and slow of heart to believe all that the prophets have spoken!
scriptures.context_description: This is Jesus’ reprimand to the two disciples on the road to Emmaus, before they recognize Him. They were discouraged about His death despite the resurrection reports. Jesus chides them for being foolish and sluggish in faith concerning the prophecies about the Messiah’s suffering and glory. He then explains the Scriptures to them. The rebuke is that they should have understood from the prophets that the Christ had to suffer and then enter His glory. By calling them foolish and slow-hearted, Jesus is firmly correcting their lack of understanding and belief.

scriptures.text: Why are you troubled, and why do doubts arise in your hearts?
scriptures.context_description: When the risen Jesus appears to the larger group of disciples (who think He might be a ghost), He asks this double question. It’s a mild rebuke of their fear and skepticism in that moment. Jesus had repeatedly told them He would rise, yet they’re startled and doubting. The questions call them out for being alarmed and harboring doubts instead of faith, even as He stands among them alive. He then shows them His wounds and eats fish to prove He’s real. This gentle challenge nudges them toward faith and calm instead of panic and unbelief.

scriptures.text: Woman, what does this have to do with me? My hour has not yet come.
scriptures.context_description: At the wedding in Cana, when Mary (Jesus’ mother) hints that He should do something about the wine running out, Jesus responds with this statement. Addressing her as “Woman” (a respectful term in that culture, but not warm like “Mother”) and essentially asking why she involves Him, He implies that performing a public miracle isn’t yet part of His divine timetable (“my hour has not yet come”). While not rude, His tone is distancing and corrective, gently rebuking Mary’s attempt to prompt Him. He does go on to perform the miracle of water to wine, but His initial response establishes that He acts on the Father’s timing, not human pressure.

scriptures.text: Take these things away; do not make my Father’s house a house of trade.
scriptures.context_description: During the first cleansing of the temple in John’s Gospel, Jesus drives out the merchants and money changers. He commands those selling pigeons, “Take these things away!” and declares they must not turn His Father’s house (the temple) into a marketplace. This is both a physical and verbal forceful action. He’s angrily rebuking them for corrupting the sacred space of worship with commercial activity. The zeal of this interaction fulfills Psalm 69:9 and sets a tone of righteous anger at greed in the temple.

scriptures.text: Are you the teacher of Israel and yet you do not understand these things?
scriptures.context_description: Jesus says this to Nicodemus, a Pharisee and prominent teacher, during their night-time conversation about being born again. Nicodemus is confused by Jesus’ teaching on spiritual rebirth. Jesus expresses astonishment and mild reproach that a renowned Jewish teacher lacks understanding of these spiritual truths (which were foreshadowed in Scripture). This question chides Nicodemus for his ignorance despite his status, implying he should know such things. It’s a corrective challenge pushing Nicodemus to recognize the depth of what Jesus is revealing.

scriptures.text: You are right in saying, 'I have no husband'; for you have had five husbands, and the one you now have is not your husband.
scriptures.context_description: In conversation with the Samaritan woman at the well, Jesus tells her to call her husband. When she evasively says she has no husband, Jesus responds with this statement, revealing His knowledge of her life. By recounting her five past husbands and current unmarried relationship, Jesus confronts her sin and brokenness directly but without harsh condemnation. It functions as a truthful exposure of her situation, leading her to perceive He is a prophet. It’s an uncomfortable but necessary part of the dialogue that leads to her transformation.

scriptures.text: Unless you see signs and wonders you will not believe.
scriptures.context_description: When a royal official begs Jesus to heal his dying son (John 4:46-49), Jesus first utters this remark, apparently addressed not only to the man but broadly (the “you” here is plural in Greek). It’s a lament or rebuke of the Galileans’ reliance on miracles for faith. Essentially, Jesus is criticizing a faith that depends on seeing miracles. It might sound discouraging, but the official persists in faith, and Jesus does heal the son. Still, this statement highlights Jesus’ frustration with people’s demand for signs as a basis for belief.

scriptures.text: See, you are well! Sin no more, that nothing worse may happen to you.
scriptures.context_description: Later on, Jesus finds the man He healed at the Bethesda pool (the man who had been lame for 38 years). Jesus gives him a warning: now that he’s physically well, he must stop sinning lest something worse befall him. “Something worse” could imply eternal judgment or a worse condition. This indicates that, in this man’s case, his past sin may have been linked to his ailment or that continued sin could result in severe consequences. Jesus’ words are a sober admonishment to pursue holiness after healing.

scriptures.text: But I know that you do not have the love of God within you.
scriptures.context_description: Speaking to the Jewish religious leaders (John 5:39-47) who opposed Him, Jesus makes this indictment. Despite their study of Scripture, their refusal to accept Him shows they lack genuine love for God. Telling them flat-out that God’s love isn’t in them is a strong rebuke, essentially accusing them of being estranged from God even as they claim to represent Him. It’s part of a broader chastisement that they seek human approval rather than God’s, leading to their rejection of the One whom God sent.

scriptures.text: Truly, truly, I say to you, you are seeking me, not because you saw signs, but because you ate your fill of the loaves.
scriptures.context_description: After feeding the 5,000, the crowd follows Jesus to the other side of the lake. Jesus confronts their motivation: they are chasing Him not out of true understanding (the “sign” pointing to Him as Messiah), but simply because they got a free meal. This is a frank rebuke of their shallow desire for physical food rather than spiritual truth. It sets the stage for His Bread of Life discourse, but many end up offended and leaving. Jesus’ candor here calls out their earthly-mindedness.

scriptures.text: But I said to you that you have seen me and yet do not believe.
scriptures.context_description: In the Bread of Life discourse, Jesus points out the crowd’s unbelief. Though they literally saw Him and witnessed His miracles (including the feeding), they still don’t trust in Him as the Son of God. This statement carries a note of reproach for their hard hearts. Jesus is emphasizing that even direct exposure to Him isn’t enough for those unwilling to believe, underlining their responsibility in their unbelief.

scriptures.text: Do not grumble among yourselves.
scriptures.context_description: When Jesus said He is the bread from heaven, the Jews began murmuring because they knew His human family and couldn’t accept His heavenly origin (John 6:41-42). Jesus responds with this command to stop grumbling. It’s a curt directive to cease their under-the-breath complaining. By telling them not to grumble, Jesus is implicitly warning them that their murmuring attitude is wrong—much like Israel in the wilderness. He then continues to explain spiritual truths. The injunction itself is a minor rebuke aimed at their resistant attitude.

scriptures.text: Did I not choose you, the Twelve? And yet one of you is a devil.
scriptures.context_description: After many disciples turn away over the hard teaching about eating His flesh, Jesus asks the Twelve if they will leave too. Peter affirms their faith. Jesus then soberly reminds them He chose them, yet one among them is “a devil.” This refers to Judas (as John 6:71 clarifies). Calling Judas “a devil” is extremely strong—indicating Judas is aligned with the enemy. Jesus is voicing the tragic reality that one hand-picked disciple harbors betrayal. It’s a negative, ominous statement meant to hint at Judas’s coming treachery and possibly to warn Judas that Jesus knows his heart.

scriptures.text: The world cannot hate you, but it hates me because I testify about it that its works are evil.
scriptures.context_description: Speaking to His brothers (who did not yet believe in Him and were urging Him to show Himself publicly), Jesus contrasts their relationship with the world versus His. He tells them the world doesn’t hate them (implying they are still of the world), but it does hate Him since He exposes its evil. This remark contains an implicit critique of His brothers’ unbelief and alignment with worldly perspectives. It’s somewhat sharp: it suggests they are not experiencing persecution because they haven’t taken a stand with Him. Meanwhile, it explains why He is hated – because He speaks uncomfortable truth about people’s sins.

scriptures.text: Has not Moses given you the law? Yet none of you keeps the law. Why do you seek to kill me?
scriptures.context_description: Speaking to the crowd in Jerusalem (which included religious leaders) at the Feast of Tabernacles, Jesus calls out their failure to keep the very Law of Moses they boast in. Despite having the law, they violate it—evidenced ultimately by their plot to kill Him (murder being against the law). This is a direct accusation especially aimed at the authorities who are plotting His death. The crowd denies having a demon and being out to kill Him (some were unaware of the leaders’ plans), but Jesus here unmasks the murderous intent in their midst and the hypocrisy of claiming to follow Moses while wanting to kill the one Moses wrote about.

scriptures.text: Do not judge by appearances, but judge with right judgment.
scriptures.context_description: Still addressing the Jerusalem crowd who were upset that He healed on a Sabbath, Jesus admonishes them to stop judging superficially. They had criticized His healing as unlawful because it was on the Sabbath, yet they would perform circumcision on the Sabbath to keep the law. Jesus points out that their judgment is flawed and hypocritical. “Judge with right judgment” is a corrective command—telling them to use righteous criteria (like mercy and the true intent of the law) rather than shallow appearances or technicalities. It’s a mild rebuke wrapped in an instruction to be fair and discerning.

scriptures.text: Let him who is without sin among you be the first to throw a stone at her.
scriptures.context_description: When the scribes and Pharisees brought a woman caught in adultery to Jesus, hoping to trap Him into contradicting the Law of Moses or Roman law, Jesus responds with this famous challenge. By saying that only a sinless person may cast the first stone, He convicts the consciences of her accusers. One by one, they depart without condemning her. Jesus’ words expose their hypocrisy and sinfulness, effectively rebuking their presumption to judge her. It’s simultaneously a masterful avoidance of their trap and a piercing indictment of their hearts.

scriptures.text: You know neither me nor my Father. If you knew me, you would know my Father also.
scriptures.context_description: During a debate in the temple treasury, the Pharisees questioned Jesus’ testimony about Himself, asking, “Where is your Father?” Jesus replies with this sharp spiritual indictment: they don’t truly know Him or God the Father. Despite their religious status, they lack genuine knowledge of God, evidenced by their failure to recognize God’s Son. This is a direct blow to their spiritual pride. Jesus ties knowing Him to knowing the Father, basically telling these experts in religion that they have missed both. It’s a deep rebuke of their spiritual condition.

scriptures.text: You are from below; I am from above. You are of this world; I am not of this world.
scriptures.context_description: Still addressing the unbelieving Jewish leaders, Jesus draws a stark contrast between them and Himself. By saying they are “from below” and “of this world,” He means they belong to a realm of earthly, sinful origin. In contrast, He claims a heavenly origin (“from above”) and that He’s not of this worldly system. This is a confrontational statement implying their values and mindset are earthly and opposed to God. It underscores why they don’t accept Him—because of fundamentally different origins and allegiances. It’s implicitly a rebuke, demoting their spiritual standing while affirming His.

scriptures.text: Unless you believe that I am he you will die in your sins.
scriptures.context_description: Jesus issues this warning to the Jewish audience (particularly the leaders) in the temple. “I am he” in context means the Messiah or the Divine One (even alluding to God’s name “I Am”). Jesus warns that if they don’t believe in His identity, they will die guilty, unforgiven for their sins. Telling devout religious individuals that they will die in sin is a grave and offensive statement to them. It’s a negative prediction conditioned on their refusal to accept Him—a last chance type of warning that salvation hinges on believing in Him.

scriptures.text: I know that you are offspring of Abraham; yet you seek to kill me because my word finds no place in you.
scriptures.context_description: Jesus acknowledges to His Jewish listeners that they are physical descendants of Abraham, but then points out the inconsistency: they are trying to kill Him. He explains the reason—they have no room in their hearts for His teaching (“my word finds no place in you”). This is a condemning statement that their murderous intent proves they’re not true spiritual children of Abraham. It directly challenges their self-perception and reveals the hostility in their hearts as evidence of their rejection of God’s word.

scriptures.text: You are of your father the devil, and your will is to do your father’s desires...
scriptures.context_description: This is one of Jesus’ most blistering rebukes to the unbelieving Jewish leaders. He flatly tells them that their true father is the devil, not God or even Abraham. He explains that they carry out the devil’s desires—implying lies and murder (as the verse continues to describe Satan as a murderer and liar). Essentially, Jesus is saying their hatred and intention to kill Him align them as children of Satan. This is extremely offensive to them but Jesus says it to unmask the true spiritual source behind their opposition. It’s a severe condemnation of their character and actions.

scriptures.text: But you have not known him. I know him. If I were to say that I do not know him, I would be a liar like you...
scriptures.context_description: As the confrontation in John 8 peaks, Jesus asserts that He knows God the Father, unlike His opponents who do not truly know God. He then adds that if He were to deny His relationship with the Father, He’d be a liar “like you.” Calling them liars to their face is strong. It references their earlier claim that God is their Father (8:41) and flips it—accusing them of falsehood. This statement accuses them of lacking genuine knowledge of God and equates their integrity with outright lying. It’s a direct insult aimed at their honesty and their spiritual knowledge.

scriptures.text: If you were blind, you would have no guilt; but now that you say, 'We see,' your guilt remains.
scriptures.context_description: After healing the man born blind, Jesus speaks to some Pharisees who ask if they too are blind. Jesus replies with this paradoxical statement. Essentially, He says if they acknowledged their spiritual blindness (ignorance), they would not be guilty (because they would seek sight). But since they arrogantly claim to see (to have spiritual insight), they remain guilty in their sin. This is a rebuke of their pride and refusal to admit need. Jesus turns their question into a pronouncement of judgment: their supposed sight is exactly what condemns them, because it’s false. It’s a cutting conclusion that leaves the self-assured Pharisees indicted.

scriptures.text: I have shown you many good works from the Father; for which of them are you going to stone me?
scriptures.context_description: When the Jewish leaders picked up stones to execute Jesus for blasphemy (after He said “I and the Father are one”), Jesus confronts them with this question. It’s a pointed challenge highlighting the irrationality of their violence. He had performed numerous miracles (“good works”) by God’s power among them. Jesus asks which miracle is the reason they want to kill Him. The implication is that none of His works deserve stoning and their real motive is their refusal to accept His claims about Himself. This question shames them and forces them to articulate that it’s not the works but what He said (claiming divinity) that offends them. It’s an ironic and bold rebuke couched in a question.

scriptures.text: Why do you ask me? Ask those who have heard me what I said to them; they know what I said.
scriptures.context_description: When being interrogated by the high priest Annas about His disciples and teaching, Jesus responds with this challenge. He points out that His ministry was public: He taught openly in synagogues and the temple, so witnesses should be available. “Why question me?” implies that the proper legal process would be to question witnesses rather than trying to trap Him by His own words. This answer is a subtle rebuke of the illegality and unfairness of the trial. One of the officers strikes Jesus for it (John 18:22). Jesus’ response here calls out the hypocrisy of the proceedings and shifts the burden back to His accusers.

scriptures.text: If what I said is wrong, bear witness about the wrong; but if what I said is right, why do you strike me?
scriptures.context_description: After Jesus’ reply to Annas, an officer slapped Him, saying “Is that how you answer the high priest?” Jesus responds with this calm but firm retort. He basically demands justification: if He spoke wrongly, they should explain how; if He spoke rightly, then the slap was unjustified. This is a dignified rebuke of the abuse He just suffered and the lack of due process. Jesus calls out the officer’s action as baseless if they cannot prove Him wrong. It’s a moment where Jesus, though on trial, asserts the principle of justice against an act of brutality.

scriptures.text: You would have no authority over me at all unless it had been given you from above. Therefore he who delivered me over to you has the greater sin.
scriptures.context_description: Speaking to Pontius Pilate during His trial, Jesus corrects Pilate’s assertion of power. Pilate had said he had authority to crucify or release Jesus (John 19:10). Jesus replies that any authority Pilate has is granted by God (“from above”). He also implies that the Jewish authorities (“he who delivered me over to you” – likely Caiaphas or Judas as representative) bear a greater guilt in this situation than Pilate does. While not directly insulting Pilate, Jesus’ statement humbles the Roman governor by reminding him that he’s not ultimately in charge. It also assigns moral responsibility, saying those who orchestrated the betrayal and handed Jesus over commit a worse offense. It’s a measured rebuke of human pride and a clarification of sin hierarchy in the injustice Jesus is undergoing.

scriptures.text: Have you believed because you have seen me? Blessed are those who have not seen and yet have believed.
scriptures.context_description: (Note: This verse appears in both positive and negative lists because it contains a mild reproof to Thomas while pronouncing a blessing.) After Thomas sees the risen Jesus and believes, Jesus asks this question. The query gently chastises Thomas for requiring physical sight to believe. Jesus then pronounces a beatitude on those who believe without seeing (which includes future believers). The implication is that Thomas’s faith, while real now, was inferior in that it demanded evidence. Thus, Jesus simultaneously encourages faith without sight and, in doing so, implicitly corrects Thomas’s earlier skepticism.

scriptures.text: If it is my will that he remain until I come, what is that to you? You follow me!
scriptures.context_description: After Jesus tells Peter about the manner of his future death (John 21:18-19), Peter notices John and asks, “Lord, what about this man?” Jesus responds with this blunt statement. Essentially, He tells Peter that John’s destiny is not Peter’s concern. Even if Jesus wanted John to live until His return, it shouldn’t affect Peter’s obedience. “What is that to you?” is a firm reproof of Peter’s curiosity or possible jealousy. Jesus then reissues the command to Peter: “You follow me!” This corrects Peter’s distraction and refocuses him on his own call of discipleship, rather than comparing to others.
